title: Virginia Woolf - Fiction and Nonfiction (12 books)
description:
VIRGINIA WOOLF  (1882-1941) was an English writer and one of the foremost modernists of the twentieth century.

During the interwar period, Woolf was a significant figure in London literary society and a central figure in the influential Bloomsbury Group of intellectuals.  Her most famous works include the novels MRS DALLOWAY (1925), TO THE LIGHTHOUSE (1927) and ORLANDO (1928), and the book-length essay A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN (1929), with its famous dictum, "A woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction."  Woolf suffered from severe bouts of mental illness throughout her life, thought to have been the result of what is now termed bipolar disorder, and committed suicide by drowning in 1941 at the age of 59.

With one exception, the files here are all retail ePUBs or PDFs.  The exception is the most recent edition of Woolf's COMPLETE WORKS, compiled and handsomely presented by Pynch and posted on mobileread.com, which includes 8 novels, 3 "biographies", 46 short stories, 606 essays, 1 play, her diary and some letters.


The following books are ePUB format unless otherwise noted:

* COMPLETE WORKS (Feb. 2014).  Compiled and edited by Pynch.

* MRS. DALLOWAY (Everyman's Library, 1993).  With an Introduction by Nadia Fusini.

* MRS. DALLOWAY (Penguin Classics, 1992).  With an Introduction and Notes by Elaine Showalter.

* NIGHT AND DAY (Barnes & Noble Classics, 2005).  With an Introduction and Notes by Rachel Wetzsteon.

* ON BEING ILL (Hogarth, 1930). -- PDF

* ORLANDO: A Biography (Penguin Classics, 1993).  Edited by Brenda Lyons with an Introduction and Notes by Sandra M. Gilbert.

* A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN (Grafton, 1977). -- PDF

* A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN (Penguin, 2004).

* TO THE LIGHTHOUSE (Penguin Classics, 1992).  Edited by Stella McNichol with an Introduction and Notes by Hermione Lee.

* THE VOYAGE OUT (Modern Library, 2001).  With and Introduction by Michael Cunningham and Notes by Deborah Lutz.

* A WRITER'S DIARY (Harcourt, 1982).

* THE YEARS (Wiley-Blackwell, 2012).  Edited by David Bradshaw and Ian Blyth. -- PDF
